_Every_ MOBA has 5 bans per team.

Except League.

It has to be the special snowflake and screwing over it's playerbase.

*55% win rate in lower-tier ranks.

Diamond +, Garen/Skarner become a non-factor and Darius is in like 10th place. Master tier, the only rework near the top is morde.

It's almost as if _the highest tier of players easily adapt to a new strategy._ Wanna know why I don't want these guys nerfed? Because the community won't learn a thing. I'm almost sure 90% of people are still picking the same stuff into guys like Darius, Skarner and Garen. Kiting seems to be such a foreign concept that people don't understand you can actually do it. 

If Riot nerfs these guys, we're going back into the cycle we've had since S2. Release something that's strong. NOT OP, but strong, and then have the community cry about it until it gets nerfed and the old picks come back while everyone complains about the lack of diversity. 

It happened with Zed. Darius. Naut. Sejuani. etc. Yet the community doesn't learn. You guys will keep crying for nerfs instead of adapting and then you'll make some long-ass post about how diversity is so small. Heads up: They just gave you a ton of diversity and strong picks. 

It's been less than a month and already we're asking to completely gut this. SMH.

I'm so happy those 6,716 Master+ players are enjoying themselves. Meanwhile, the rest of the planet's 10,482,200 LoL players would rather Ekko-ulti IRL back to 5.14. 

Balance the game for the 10 million ranked players on earth who don't enjoy being devourer-deleted or steamrolled by Garen who is literally the easiest, most idiot-proof champ in the entire game.
No, you can't balance for the lowest common denominator in ANY game. You need to balance for the highest possible skillcap, because that's the way the game is meant to be played.

Professionals who make up .064% of the playerbase do not dictate how the game is "meant to be played." We don't all have to quit our jobs and play League 100 hours per week with a paid coach to play League "properly." What an idiotic notion.

It's even more idiotic when you consider these numbers from NA Summer LCS:

Champs picked 0 times:  25
Champs picked 1-5 times: 27

Gragas - a single champ - was played in more games than the **bottom 75 champs combined.**

My point is that if 60% of the champ pool is already essentially unplayable in LCS, and 20% of the champ pool is already literally not played in LCS, then it doesn't really matter whether Garen and Darius, et al are played in LCS. 

It's perfectly fine for them to join the ranks of Nasus, Malzahar, Talon, Amumu, Lux, etc. who do quite well for the 10 million players using them in solo/duo without being total cancer.

TL;DR: If champs were actually balanced for LCS, you wouldn't have of them be essentially useless in LCS. Your premise is completely incorrect because statistics.

The reason champs aren't used in lcs is because they try and find an awkward middle ground.  Fighters balance for the highest skillcap, shooters do as well. Why should this be any different? 

Just yesterday in battlefield 4, they game the revolvers slight nerfs even though the general perception of the community was they were crap anyways. They actually had some insane potential, with the ability to one shot in the head at pretty absurd ranges for a sidearm, hence they were nerfed, because some people could do it. That's proper balancing.

You're conflating balance and design. Your battlefield 4 example shows how poor design leads to poor balance. If skill floor is too high, most players do poorly with the champ/item. If the skill cap is too high, the top .06% of players do too well with it.

So if you nerf the damage of that item across the board, most players will do worse with the item. Some players who did alright with it will now do poorly. And only the top .06% of players will do well (just not be broken OP anymore).

And that's what we see with League, essentially. We have a few different categories to consider:

1) Too Low Skill Floor, Too Low Skill Cap:  These are the champs who do very well in all brackets outside LCS but never see LCS play. Like Heimer, Malzahar, Talon, Blitz, Udyr, etc.

2) Too High Skill Floor, Too Low Skill Cap: These are the champs who are virtually unplayed all around, despite some decent stats from dedicated players. Like Zyra, Poppy, Fiddlesticks, Zilean, etc.

3)  Too Low Skill Floor, Too High Skill Cap:  This is where champs get near-universally good results and turn into holy terrors in the right hands. LIke Fizz, Vayne, Riven, Ahri, etc.

4) Too High Skill Floor, Too High Skill Cap:  These are the champs that do badly in every bracket but get nerfed because of LCS to the point of unviability in most players' hands. LIke Evelynn, Azir, Kalista, Ryze, LeBlanc, Kassadin, etc.

The problem is that Riot "balances" by tweaking numbers far more than by changing actual mechanics. So right now, the skill floor on Annie and Garen, for example, is in the basement because their numbers are so high. Lowering their damage will increase their skill floor and bring them into balance without mechanical changes, but their low skill caps would probably keep them out of LCS.

But champs like Kalista, reducing her numbers also increases the skill floor on a champ with an already-high floor. So she becomes essentially unviable to a majority of players (not that I mind) to balance her in the LCS where her mechanics would still make her a contested pick.

Right now juggernauts are just overtuned to the point where there skill floor is so low that almost anyone can just go ham all game, lose lane, feed early, and still win. If the lower numbers keep them out of LCS, I'm fine with that. They'll have plenty of company with the 50% of champs that see negligible or zero play who do just fine for the 10M other players.

How is that poor design? The people at the top are the only people capable of playing the game properly the way it was meant to be played. The best can fully flesh it out. Revolvers were arguably too strong at the highest level of play, (Where the game is being played properly), so they nerfed it. It's two different games between bronze and challenger, and you need to give more to the people who use all the games mechanics to it's fullest potential.

"...you need to give more to the people who use all the games mechanics to it's fullest potential."

Except this already isn't happening because 50%+ champs are either unviable or suboptimal in LCS. So Riot is already failing at balance on both ends. If that's already the case (and it's not changing), the enjoyment of 10M players should take priority over LCS.

I feel like I'm talking to a brick wall.

The middle ground negotiation has helped to result in this 50%+ champion unviability, mind you. High level play and low level play both suffer when Riot tries to balance for both low level play and high level play. 

Now, the deal with which they should choose is: Which one of them is being actively paid to play this game? It sure as hell isn't the Bronze players, or us Unranked players. So, since professionals are being paid to play this game at its highest potential, or at least their highest potential, then the balance of the game should fall on.. Them. 

Think about it: Nothing else really balances around amateur activity. They may facilitate and help it along to give it a decent start, but they don't balance around it. Fighting games don't balance around amateurs, they balance around the professionals. FPS games don't balance around amateurs, they balance around the professionals. RTS games don't balance around amateurs, they balance around the professionals. DotA doesn't balance around us amateurs, they balance around the professionals.

Why should League be any different? The other MOBAs don't even balance around amateur play, why should League? Many people want to have fun, as games are here for, and they can continue to do that with a game balanced around professional play (yes, you can still have ridiculous fun in DotA, for instance). Many other people want a good competitive game, which they'll get a much better fit for if the game competitive game in question is balanced around people who know what they're doing. 

Riot's problem is that they try to cater to both at the same time when they should prioritize competitive play.

"Which one of them is being actively paid to play this game? It sure as hell isn't the Bronze players, or us Unranked players. So, since professionals are being paid to play this game at its highest potential, or at least their highest potential, then the balance of the game should fall on.. Them."

Just going to point out that this is fine if your business model centers around spectators instead of players. This isn't the NFL. 

In a spectator game, your idea works in theory. But balancing around LCS in the actual game would leave the vast majority of players with an atrocious game experience and a viable champ pool in the shape of an upside-down pyramid.

In other words, Riot is not going to balance only for LCS because that would leave them with no game to balance. The current compromise isn't too awful, all things considered.

But the point is that it still matters not one iota if juggernauts are nerfed out of LCS to benefit overall game health. It makes zero sense that so many champs have (and will be) nerfed out of LCS for overall game health but the juggernauts should be untouchable only because they aren't problematic for pros.

How does it make no sense? Most champs that do see major nerfs are due to being super strong in LCS. Many many many azir nerfs. Elise nerfs a while back. Lee sin nerfs. Most of the patches are for nerfing things. Also, neat little thing, riot dosen't WANT every champion to be viable at once. Someone did a video, don't remember who called "perfect imbalance". You should look into it sometime.
